Message.Title: Seriously, is nvda Really worth a PE of 17.11?
Message.Msg: - Irrational Exuberance today bid nvda to north of $14.00, boys. To a PE of 17.11 Which begs the question, is nvda Really worth that nose-bleed multiple? 17.11 times earnings. The answer of course, is found in Relativity. How does nvda's multiple compare to other, better companies in their sector. In a relative sense. So let's compare earnings multiples, shall we? Price/Earnings Ratio Trailing twelve months earnings Source: Yahoo Finance 17.11 __ nvidia 14.98 __ Microsoft Corporation 14.63 __ Apple Inc. 14.44 __ IBM 13.01 __ The Entire Semiconductor Industry 11.31 __ Samsung Electronics Co. Ltd 11.17 __ Intel Corporation 7.27 ___ Hewlett-Packard Co. Is nvda Really worth 17 times earnings -- where Apple is valued at a PE of 14.6? Hummm? Or is nvda worthy of a multiple 6 times Higher than Intel or Samsung Electronics? The answer: Nope. It isn't. nvda is shrinking year-over-year in the only Department that matters, -- the Earnings Per Share Department -- and the others are Growing. Take Apple for example. First Call EPS Estimates for the year are as follows: $27.68 __ Actual for YE 9/30/11 $44.16 __ Consensus for YE 9/30/12 Really really nice growth in Apple earnings, right? And it trades for a multiple of 14.63 times earnings. Now let's compare that to nvda. First Call EPS Estimates for the year are as follows: $0.94 __ Actual for YE 1/31/12 $0.69 __ Consensus for YE 1/31/13 nvda's earnings are Shrinking. And shrinking badly. According to the consensus of First Call analysts. Yet it trades at a nose-bleed multiple of 17.11 Did I mention? Irrational Exuberance has driven nvda to a ridiculous multiple. Again. And accordingly, Best today started a new short position in your precious nvda. Again. Seriously. Oh, and thanks to all those nice folks that lent Best your nvda shares. Best promises to take good care of them -- paying any dividends which have never been declared in nvidia's 18 year history -- and return 'em just as soon as the Irrational Exuberance has been wrung out, and the coming PE multiple adjustment is complete. -

Message.Msg: All the chips [sic] feature support for the latest standards including OpenGL ES 3.0 and DirectX 11. Â The latter feature is important, as it will allow ARM's GPU cores to be included on the system-on-a-chip (SoC) brains of upcoming Windows 8 tablet designs. http://www.dailytech.com/ARMs+Mali+Midgard+GPUs+Hit+the+Market+Ready+for+Tablets+Smartphones/article25345.htm Holy Tamoli Batman, time to be worried?

Topic.Title: OMG - ARM Mali "Midgard" GPUs hit the market

Message.Msg: Hit the market may be a little bit enthusiastic. What is being announced are 2nd gen Mali-T600 designs. However, first-gen Mali designs aren't even shipping in devices yet despite having launch 2 years ago. Seeing these in a consumer device before late 2013 or 2014 is unlikely.

Message.Title: CPUs & GPUs & Costs
Message.Msg: Everybody pays Arm a royalty for using Arm CPUs in one form or another. Similarly Ti, Samsung, Apple pays the leading GPU - Imagination PowerVR or Arm for the Mali GPUs. The only company with a credible high performance GPU and not have to pay royalties is Nvidia. Quallcom with the Adreno GPUs is not in the same class - they pump it to be - the reality is the Poor guys realized only recently that Adreno doesn't cut it and they had to license the Imagination PowerVR adding another layer of royalty for each chip sold. Adreno is good for playing Angry Birds and Zynga in high performance mode - Birds gets angrier and Zynga games gets more Zyngged. Now, it's not just the royalties increasing costs that is the problem - the performance, die size and power dissipation of these cores are almost certainly not as optimal as Nvidia's GPUs as well. It's easy to add more cores to get performance - but you are adding costs and power at the same time and increasing the battery size of the end product increasing costs yet again. If the 1st generation Apple A5 (Dual core dual PowerVR GPU 122mm2 45nm) had gone into the Nexus 7 - they wouldn't be able to sell it for $199 - the T3 Quad CPU in 40nm is only 80mm2! Now you can argue that T3 could have had 24 GPUs instead of 12GPUs and still cost less than the A5 - sure but it would not have met the $199 target and it would have required a larger battery to boot. Sure helps when you have a great die size, no GPU royalties and deliver a great performance using yesterday's technology. Mr Joe Six Pack don't care about a Quad 28nm costing $1300 he cares about a Quad costing as close to ZERO as possible. If the GPU performance measurements include having to perform the exact Physxs that games using the T3 uses all the other GPUs would CROAK! The 4+1 CPU architecture in 40nm is truly amazing - the fact that that it can almost go toe to toe with a DUAL core at 28nm in terms of power dissipation is just amazing. Normally you would expect a 50% improvement between a Quad core at 40nm compared to a Quad core at 28nm and perhaps a 60% advantage for the Dual S4 at 28nm - instead it's barely a 10% overall advantage. The analysts are clueless and QCOM people are shamelessly touting their 10% advantage! It would be interesting to see 4+1 for T4.

Topic.Title: Bloomberg: Apple ties to Samsung in sharp contrast to courtroom clash

Message.Msg: Ibexx, in regards to Apple finding alternate suppliers, along with Apple doing business with TSCM, & with Nvidia back as a vendor, what do you think of my theory that Apple has been working with TSCM & Nvidia for some time already on building a custom Tegra chip? With GeForce GRID, GTX & Project Denver, on the horizon, Apple would be assured future leading performance, expand in other high performance areas such as gaming, servers/cloud, and get further away from Samsung. As the enclosed article mentioned: âOn the surface it seems like an obvious thing to do, but actually executing it would be very expensiveâ. Since Apple has 117 billion in liquid assets, I don't see it as being any problem. "Scant Alternatives: Other chipmakers would probably welcome Appleâs business. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., the largest maker of chips to order, said last month that it was open to devoting one or more factories to a single customer. The statement was aimed at Apple or Qualcomm Inc., another maker of mobile chips, according to Sam Wang, an analyst at Gartner. Still, switching to another foundry such as TSMC would bring challenges. TSMC would have to limit orders from other customers to accommodate Appleâs needs, and it uses a different production technology than Samsung, requiring a redesign of the processors from the ground up, Wang said. TSMC rival United Microelectronics Corp. (2303) is too small, and Globalfoundries Inc. is too far behind on production technology, he said. âThereâs an incredible cost to doing that, and it would be very difficult,â said Michael Hasler, a former supply-chain management executive at chipmaker Applied Materials Inc., who now lectures at the University of Texas at Austin. âOn the surface it seems like an obvious thing to do, but actually executing it would be very expensive.â

Message.Title: Analysts set $20 target
Message.Msg: Raymond Jamesâs Hans Mosesmann, who has a Strong Buy rating on the stock, and a $20 price target, writes that âWhile broad-based PC softness may put July results at the lower end of the guidance range, this is better than peers and is mostly a short-term dynamic.â Mosesmann thinks that while the company may hit the low end of its forecast range â $990 million â there will be no âbroad-based miss,â because â1) 28nm supply constraints will keep NVIDIA more insulated from demand; and 2) we believe NVIDIA will benefit from share gains on the Ivy Bridge platform, which will also likely give it an advantage in the upcoming wave of Ultrabooks.â Rajvindra Gill of Needham & Co. reiterates a Buy rating on the shares, and a $20 price target. He thinks the company can âmeet or beatâ the forecast, with GPU revenue rising perhaps 10%, quarter over quarter, âdriven by the ramp of Apple (AAPL) (add $30MM/qrt or 5% of Q/Q growth)â plus gaining share from Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) with other notebook makers.â Gill sees revenue from the companyâs âTegraâ application processor rising 35%, quarter over quarter, to $110 million, comprising 7 million units at an average selling price of $15. FBR Capitalâs Craig Berger is in agreement with Mosesmann that revenue was on the low side, relative to the forecast. He observes âPC builds were weak in June and July, affecting GPU sales,â and its possible the forecast for this quarter will be $1.02 billion to $1.07 billion, below the Streetâs âseemingly stale $1.10B.â But Berger also thinks thereâs âupsideâ come October because of the introduction of Microsoftâs (MSFT) Windows 8, and upside as well from new tablet computers running Tegra. (For example, Googleâs (GOOG) âNexus 7.â) And like Mosesmann, he thinks âNVIDIA should benefit from ramping 28 nm Kepler exposure with improving gross margins.â http://blogs.barrons.com/techtraderdaily/2012/08/07/nvda-fyq2-street-says-look-to-28-nano-ramp-win-8/?mod=yahoobarrons

Message.Title: Will Apple use custom Tegra chip?
Message.Msg: Since Apple is actively looking for alternate suppliers, and is now doing business with TSCM, & Nvidia, what's the possibility that Apple has been working with TSCM & Nvidia for some time on creating a custom Tegra chip? With GeForce GRID, GTX & Project Denver on the horizon, Apple would be assured future leading performance, expand in other high performance/profitable areas such as gaming, servers/cloud, and get further away from Samsung. As the enclosed article mentioned: âOn the surface it seems like an obvious thing to do, but actually executing it would be very expensiveâ. Since Apple has 117 billion in liquid assets, I don't see it as being any problem. I would be interested in hearing from Ibexx, Schmenkle, along with other valued posters about the said possibility? âThereâs an incredible cost to doing that, and it would be very difficult,â said Michael Hasler, a former supply-chain management executive at chipmaker Applied Materials Inc., who now lectures at the University of Texas at Austin. âOn the surface it seems like an obvious thing to do, but actually executing it would be very expensive.â http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-08-07/apple-ties-to-samsung-in-sharp-contrast-to-courtoom-clash.html

Topic.Title: Seriously, is nvda Really worth a PE of 17.11?

Message.Msg: - Cash supports the ridiculous multiple of earnings? HA HA HA HA HA HA HA! Cash is ethereal and diaphanous. It is here today, and maybe gone tomorrow. Like Knight Capital's $450 million of cash. That disappeared in an electronic screw-up last week. Cash is impermanent, delicate, fragile and transient. Just one more bad acquisisition by Jen. One more major product recall or lawsuit lost. And Poof! That cash is gone gone gone. With absolutely nothing to show for it. Nada. One more Icera acquisition. But a mere six times larger. And nvidia has no cash -- and no earnings from it either. Just like the $367 million of cash burned on the Icera acquisition. Only a ridiculous multiple of shrinking Earnings remains. You are a fool to justify an unwarranted Price/Earnings multiple based on ethereal and impermanent cash. -
